values: Enforce 30 km/h speed limit on all road and trail segments.
Maintain a minimum 50 m spacing between vehicles.
Designate ground guides at all intersections, tight turns, and low‑visibility areas.
Use NVG‑compatible hand/arm signals and radio check‑ins every 5 minutes.
Conduct a pre‑movement convoy brief covering route, hazards, and emergency procedures.
Convoy brief led by Serial OIC, ground guides positioned by VC team, continuous radio traffic monitoring.
Serial OIC, Vehicle Crews (VCs), Ground Guides, Squad Leaders
All loads must be inspected against the Load Plan and Bump Plan before movement.
Tie‑downs must be double‑checked for proper tension and redundancy.
Use a pre‑movement PCC/PCI checklist that includes load‑secure verification.
Assign a designated Load Inspector for each vehicle.
PCC/PCI conducted by CO/1SG and designated Inspectors, written sign‑off on Marshalling Checklist.
CO, 1SG, Assigned Inspectors, Vehicle Crews
Complete PMCS and functional check the morning of 30 MAY before vehicles enter the yard.
Verify serviceability of headlights, taillights, and NVG‑compatible lighting.
Confirm brakes, steering, and tire pressure are within spec.
Document findings on DA Form 5987 and attach to dispatch book.
PMCS performed by vehicle crews, reviewed by OIC/NCOIC, any deficiencies rectified before inspection.
Vehicle Crews, OIC, NCOIC, Maintenance Personnel
Ensure each vehicle carries a serviceable fire extinguisher.
Store all flammable liquids in approved containers and label HAZMAT placards where required.
Keep warning triangles and first‑aid kits in the vehicle at all times.
Conduct a fire‑extinguishing drill during the pre‑movement brief.
Safety brief by RSO, visual inspection of extinguishers, verify HAZMAT placards.
RSO, Vehicle Crews, Safety NCO
Assign a medic to each vehicle convoy segment.
Equip each vehicle with a MEV‑compatible first‑aid kit.
Establish a CASEVAC communications plan (Wickr/ATAK hand‑off) and 9‑line brief format.
Conduct a casualty evacuation drill before SP.
Medical brief by HHT medic, confirm MEV location, test radio/phone contact with range medical element.
Assigned Medic, RSO, Convoy Commander, Vehicle Crews
Validate all ATAK devices and Wickr handles before SP.
Conduct a PACE check (Primary, Alternate, Contingency, Emergency) for each communication platform.
Pre‑designate an alternate FM radio frequency for convoy command.
Include a communications SOP in the Marshalling Checklist.
Comm‑check conducted during PCC, log sign‑off on checklist.
Signal NCO, Serial OIC, Vehicle Crews
All personnel must wear NVGs and be proficient in NVG‑compatible vehicle navigation.
Mark all lane boundaries and hazards with reflective tape or chem‑lights.
Conduct a night‑vision briefing covering glare, depth perception, and eye safety.
NVG proficiency check performed by RSO during pre‑movement brief.
RSO, Vehicle Crews, Squad Leaders
Enforce a minimum 8‑hour rest period before the marshalling event.
Schedule a 30‑minute rest break mid‑inspection.
Monitor crew alertness during PCC/PCI and during the night maneuver.
Leadership conducts welfare check at 1100 and 1500, documents any signs of fatigue.
Platoon Leader, Squad Leaders, Vehicle Crews

overall_supervision_plan: The OIC, RSO, and HHT leadership will conduct a comprehensive pre‑event briefing covering all hazard controls.  Convoy leaders will supervise PCC/PCI inspections, enforce speed and spacing, and verify that all communication, medical, and fire‑suppression assets are in place.  Continuous supervision will be maintained through ground guides, safety NCOs, and periodic personnel welfare checks to ensure the residual risk remains low.
mission_task_and_description: 3/2CR, HHT conducts marshalling preparation on 30MAY25 to familiarize vehicle crews with marshalling procedures and prepare Hammer TRP for future Troop TRMs.
